speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe when you first noticed the decreased vision and black spots in your right eye, was it sudden or gradual?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about 2 days ago, to be honest, I was watching TV and I noticed the screen was a bit fuzzy, but I thought it was just the TV or maybe I was tired. Then last night, I was getting ready for bed and I saw these black spots in my right eye, they're really small and they're moving, it's a bit unsettling."

speaker: Doctor
text: Did you experience any other symptoms such as eye pain, redness, or sensitivity to light, and have you noticed any similar vision problems in your left eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "I didn't feel any pain, but the spots in my right eye are kind of bothering me, and I did notice that my vision is a bit blurry, like I'm seeing double. As for the left eye, I've been feeling fine, no redness or sensitivity, just the spots in the right eye are the issue."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent weight loss, fever, or other systemic symptoms that might be related to your AIDS diagnosis, and are you currently taking any medications to manage your HIV?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I've been feeling a bit weaker than usual lately, but I couldn't pinpoint the exact cause. As for my medications, I'm taking all the prescribed treatments for my HIV and Kaposi's sarcoma, and I've been following my doctor's advice to take the medications as directed."

speaker: Doctor
text: When you say you noticed decreased vision and black spots, can you describe the black spots in more detail - are they moving, fixed, or do they seem to be floating in front of your eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're really small, about the size of a pinhead, and they're definitely moving, like they're floating in front of my eye. Sometimes they seem to be moving closer to my pupil, and other times they're farther away, it's a bit disorienting to be honest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the size, shape, or number of the black spots, and do they seem to be more noticeable when you're looking at bright lights or in certain environments?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, yes, the spots seem to be getting a bit bigger, and they're also moving more quickly now. And to be honest, they seem to be more noticeable when I'm in a dimly lit room, like when I'm watching TV or reading a book, but they're not as distracting as they were earlier. I've also noticed that they seem to be more prominent when I'm looking at things up close, like my phone or a book."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current HIV treatment regimen, are you adhering to it as prescribed, and have you experienced any recent changes in your viral load or CD4 count?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm taking all my prescribed medications as directed - efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, and azithromycin for my HIV, as well as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole to prevent opportunistic infections. My doctor usually checks my viral load and CD4 count every few months, and I'm due for an appointment soon, but I haven't noticed anything out of the ordinary recently. I've been trying to stick to my routine and follow my doctor's advice, but to be honest, I've been feeling a bit tired and weak lately."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent eye exams or a dilated retinal exam, and do you have a history of any eye problems or conditions, such as retinal detachment or CMV retinitis, which can be associated with AIDS?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think I've had an eye exam in a while, I usually try to get them done when I'm due for a routine check-up with my HIV doctor, but I don't remember the last time I had one. I do have a history of Kaposi's sarcoma, though, which was diagnosed about 2 years ago, but I'm not sure if that's relevant to my current symptoms."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection or experienced any symptoms of it, such as fatigue, fever, or swollen lymph nodes, and are you currently taking any prophylactic medications to prevent CMV infection?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've had CMV before, I was diagnosed with it a few years ago, and I've been taking the prophylactic medication to prevent it from coming back, but I don't think I've had any symptoms recently. However, I do recall having some flu-like symptoms back then, and I'm not sure if that's related to CMV or something else."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current vision in your left eye, is it normal, and have you noticed any blind spots or areas of distorted vision in that eye as well?

speaker: Patient
text: "To be honest, my left eye is fine, I don't notice anything out of the ordinary. I don't see any blind spots or areas of distorted vision in that eye, just the black spots in my right eye are the issue, and my vision is a bit blurry, like I'm seeing double. It's pretty much just the right eye that's affected."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your vision at different times of the day, for example, are the black spots more noticeable in the morning or evening, and do you experience any blurred vision or difficulty focusing?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I think the black spots are more noticeable in the evening, when the lights are dimmer. It's like they're more prominent when I'm sitting in a dark room, and the blurred vision seems to be more noticeable when I'm trying to focus on something up close, like my phone or a book. Sometimes it feels like my eyes are having trouble adjusting to the light, like they're struggling to focus."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent head trauma or injuries that could have potentially caused the vision problems in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, nothing like that. I'm pretty careful about my health and I try to avoid taking unnecessary risks. I do have a bit of a rough history with opportunistic infections, though - I was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma a couple of years ago, and I've had some issues with fungal esophagitis in the past. But I don't think that's directly related to my current symptoms."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any flashing lights or zigzag patterns in your vision, and do the black spots seem to be affecting your peripheral vision or central vision more?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, actually, I have noticed some flashing lights and zigzag patterns in my vision, especially when I'm trying to focus on something. It's like my eyes are getting a bit mixed up, and the black spots seem to be affecting my central vision more, making it harder for me to see things clearly. It's pretty disorienting, to be honest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you rate the severity of your decreased vision and black spots on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being mild and 10 being severe, and has it worsened or improved since you first noticed the symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'd say it's around an 8, to be honest, it's really been affecting my daily life and I'm finding it hard to focus on things. Since I first noticed the symptoms, it's actually gotten a bit worse, the black spots seem to be moving more quickly and they're getting bigger, it's getting harder to ignore them."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe your daily activities and how the decreased vision and black spots in your right eye have affected your ability to perform tasks such as reading, driving, or watching television?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it's been pretty tough. I've had to slow down a bit when reading or watching TV, because I'm not sure what's going on in my vision, and I don't want to strain my eyes. I've also had to cancel a few plans with friends because I've been having trouble driving at night, and I'm worried about crashing into something. It's really frustrating because I'm used to being active and independent, but now I have to be more careful about my surroundings."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any difficulty with depth perception or judging distances, and have the vision problems in your right eye caused you to bump into objects or have any near falls?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, to be honest, I've been having trouble judging distances, like when I'm walking or driving. It's like my brain is having trouble telling me how far away things are, and it's making it hard for me to navigate. And yeah, I have bumped into a few things, like the couch or my chair, and it's been pretty scary, I'm just lucky I wasn't hurt badly."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current lifestyle, are you smoking or using any illicit substances, and have you noticed any changes in your appetite or sleep patterns since the onset of the vision problems?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm not really sure if my lifestyle has changed much, I mean I still smoke a pack a day and I do have a bit of a partying history, but I've been trying to cut back on that lately. As for my appetite, I've actually noticed that I've been eating less since the vision problems started, I just don't feel like cooking or eating as much as I used to. And sleep, I've been having trouble sleeping, I keep waking up during the night and feeling like my eye is bothering me, even when it's not."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current CD4 count and viral load, and have there been any recent changes in your HIV treatment regimen that may be contributing to the vision problems in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm not really sure what my CD4 count and viral load are, I usually get them checked when I go to the doctor for my regular check-up, but I haven't been to see my HIV doctor in a while. As for my treatment regimen, like I said, I'm taking all my prescribed medications as directed, but I have been feeling a bit tired and weak lately, and my doctor mentioned something about adjusting my regimen a few months ago, but I don't think that's directly related to my vision problems."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your vision when you're moving or walking, and do the black spots seem to be more noticeable when you're changing direction or moving quickly?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, actually, the black spots seem to be more noticeable when I'm changing direction or moving quickly. Like, if I'm walking down the street and I turn a corner, I'll see the spots more clearly, and if I'm running or something, they seem to be moving even more. It's like my vision is having trouble keeping up with my movements, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with any opportunistic infections related to your AIDS diagnosis, such as toxoplasmosis or cryptococcosis, which could potentially affect your vision?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. I've had some issues with opportunistic infections in the past, like fungal esophagitis and Kaposi's sarcoma, but I'm not aware of any specific opportunistic infections that could be affecting my vision right now."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any neurological symptoms such as seizures, tremors, or numbness in your face or extremities, and do you think your AIDS diagnosis could be contributing to your vision problems in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've had a few seizures in the past, about 5 years ago, but they were really minor and didn't last long. I don't think they were related to my HIV, but I do have a history of seizures, so I guess that's a possibility. As for numbness in my face or extremities, I haven't really noticed anything like that, but I do have a bit of neuropathy in my feet, which is pretty common for people with HIV, right?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet and nutrition, are you experiencing any difficulty swallowing or digesting food, and have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements or stool quality since the onset of the vision problems?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I've been eating a bit less since I started noticing these black spots, I just don't feel like cooking or eating as much as I used to. I've been relying more on takeout and delivery, and I've also been having trouble swallowing at times, especially when I'm feeling the spots in my eye. It's like my mouth is getting a bit dry and my tongue is feeling funny. I've also noticed that my stool has been a bit loose lately, and I've been experiencing some abdominal cramps, but I'm not sure if that's related to my HIV or just something else."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent changes in your mental status, such as confusion, disorientation, or memory loss, and do you think your decreased vision and black spots could be related to a neurological issue?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I haven't really noticed any changes in my mental status, I mean I've been feeling a bit tired and weak lately, but I don't think that's related to my vision. I've been trying to stay on top of my medications and follow my doctor's advice, but I don't think my vision is related to a neurological issue, I think it's more of an eye problem. I've had some trouble judging distances and depth perception, but that's about it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the color or clarity of your vision, and are the black spots more noticeable when you're looking at certain colors or objects?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I think the black spots are more noticeable when I'm looking at dark colors or shadows, it's like they're popping out more. And the colors around them seem a bit muted, like they're not as vibrant as they usually are. It's hard to describe, but it's like my vision is having trouble distinguishing between different shades of color."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent changes in your eye movements or difficulty tracking objects with your right eye, and do the black spots seem to be affecting your ability to read or watch television?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I've noticed that my right eye has been having trouble tracking objects, like when I'm watching TV or reading a book. The black spots seem to be moving around on the screen, and it's like my eye is having trouble following them. It's pretty frustrating because I'm used to being able to focus on things easily, but now I have to make a conscious effort to keep my eye on the screen."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any pus or discharge in your right eye, and have you experienced any eye itching, burning, or tearing that could be related to an infection?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. I've been cleaning my eyes regularly and I haven't noticed any discharge or pus. I have been experiencing some eye irritation, like a burning sensation, but it's more of a dull ache than anything sharp or stabbing. It's just a bit uncomfortable, to be honest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the shape and location of the black spots in your right eye - are they located in the center of your vision or more towards the periphery, and are they round, oval, or irregularly shaped?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I'm not really sure. They seem to be moving around, so I'm not sure if they're fixed in one spot. Sometimes they're in the center of my vision, and other times they're more towards the side. They're definitely not round, they seem more like little dots or specks. And they're getting bigger, like I mentioned before, so it's a bit unsettling."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the black spots when you're looking at digital screens, such as computers or smartphones, and do you think the vision problems in your right eye could be related to your AIDS diagnosis or a separate issue?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I've noticed that the black spots seem to be more noticeable when I'm looking at digital screens. Like, when I'm scrolling through my phone or browsing the internet, the spots seem to be moving around more and it's like my vision is having trouble keeping up. I'm not sure if it's related to my AIDS, but it feels like my eyes are getting a bit more tired when I'm looking at screens. I've been trying to take breaks and give my eyes a rest, but it's hard when I'm working or studying."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent changes in your blood pressure or have you been diagnosed with hypertension, which can potentially contribute to vision problems, and are you currently taking any medications to manage your blood pressure?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I don't think I've had my blood pressure checked recently. I do remember that my doctor mentioned something about adjusting my medications a few months ago, but I don't think that included anything to do with my blood pressure. I'm currently taking all the prescribed medications for my HIV and Kaposi's sarcoma, as I mentioned earlier, but I don't think I have any medications for blood pressure."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current vision in your right eye, is it blurry, and are the black spots affecting your ability to see details or read small print?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, it's definitely blurry. I mean, I can see things, but they're not really clear. The black spots are making it hard for me to read small print, like on my phone or a book. I've been trying to use larger font and just squint, but it's not really working. It's like my eye is having trouble focusing on things, even when I'm trying to concentrate."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had a fundoscopic examination or an optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan to evaluate the health of your retina, and would you be willing to undergo one today to help me better understand the cause of your vision problems?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I had a fundoscopic examination about 5 years ago, when I was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma. I also had an OCT scan a couple of years ago, but I don't think my doctor mentioned the results of those tests. I'm willing to undergo another fundoscopic examination and OCT scan today to help you better understand what's going on with my eyes. Can we do that now?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your current HIV treatment regimen, specifically what medications you are taking and what is your current viral load, and have you experienced any recent changes in your CD4 count that may be related to the vision problems in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm taking efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, and azithromycin for my HIV, as I mentioned earlier. speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your AIDS diagnosis, specifically when you were diagnosed and what was your lowest CD4 count at the time of diagnosis, and have you ever experienced any opportunistic infections that required hospitalization?

speaker: Patient
text: "I was diagnosed with AIDS about 2 years ago, I think it was around June or July of that year. My lowest CD4 count at the time was around 50, I remember my doctor mentioning that it was a pretty low count. I had to take a bunch of medications to get it under control, and I was on IV fluids for a while. It was a pretty scary time, but I'm just grateful that I was able to recover and get my CD4 count back up."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with any eye conditions, such as retinal detachment, macular edema, or endophthalmitis, which can be associated with AIDS, and are you currently taking any medications that could potentially affect your vision, such as antiretroviral therapy or corticosteroids?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your vision at night or in low-light environments, and do the black spots seem to be more noticeable when you're in a dimly lit room or outside at night?

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: Fundoscopic examination

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Fundoscopy: Bilateral retinal vasculature is normal, but multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages are present in both eyes, and granular yellow-white opacities are seen around the retinal vessels in the right eye. The macula and optic disc are otherwise unremarkable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you please wait for a few minutes while I review the results of the fundoscopic examination, and I'll be right back to ask you some more questions and possibly order some additional tests.

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll wait. It's just frustrating to not know what's going on with my eyes. I feel like I'm missing out on things because I'm too scared to drive at night or read anything small. Please hurry, I need some answers."

speaker: Doctor

text: Based on your symptoms and medical history, I'm going to make a diagnosis. Before I do, I just want to confirm one last thing: are you currently taking any medications that could potentially interact with your HIV treatment regimen or affect your vision?
